poem:
Heathrow Farewell

Excited waves  
in morning light—  
a father's hand  
raised in warm promise,  
sun on steel wings.  
No parting tears  
this time,  
only the wide,  
hopeful span of weeks.  
But now,  
cold headlines—  
gaps in time  
where words  
should braid,  
unanswered.  
Silence in echoes  
of terminal doors.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I shouldn’t have to fight for answers’: David Amess’s daughter on the MP’s murder and her fury at his friends and colleagues The last time Katie Amess saw her dad, the Conservative MP Sir David Amess, he was dropping her at Heathrow for her flight home to Los Angeles. Usually, she would cry when they said goodbye, but this time neither were sad – they were both excited. In six weeks, Katie would be back". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
